statements.name: PROC TSMODEL
statements.description: The TSMODEL procedure is a SAS Viya procedure that executes user-defined programs on time series data. The TSMODEL procedure analyzes timestamped transactional data with respect to time and accumulates the data into a time series format. † The TSMODEL procedure forms time series from input timestamped transactional data and writes the accumulated time series variables to an output table. Time series are delineated based on the distinct values of the variables that are listed in the BY statement.

arguments.name: AUXDATA=
arguments.description: Names a table that contains auxiliary input data for the procedure to use for supplying time series variables. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to the caslib and session identifier, and data-table specifies the name of the input data table.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the input data table for PROC TSMODEL to use. The default is the most recently created data table. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to a collection of information that is defined in the LIBNAME statement and includes the caslib, which includes a path to the data, and a session identifier, which defaults to the active session but which can be explicitly defined in the LIBNAME statement.

arguments.name: INOBJ=
arguments.description: Specifies pairs, each of which binds a repeater object specified by object-name with an input table specified by CAS-libref.data-table. You can specify one or more object-table pairs as needed to associate the repeater objects that you declare in your user-defined program with their input tables. You must specify a binding for any repeater object that you declare in your program; otherwise, a parse-time error is generated when you submit the program and no execution occurs.

arguments.name: INSCALAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a table to supply scalar dynamic variables to be included and made accessible to your program code as it executes.

arguments.name: LEAD=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of periods ahead to extend time series arrays for the variables in both the VAR and OUTARRAYS statements that are output to the CAS table. You can specify this option to accommodate a forecast lead or horizon when you are preparing time series data for forecasting.

arguments.name: LOGCONTROL=
arguments.description: Specifies pairs that define error severity and associated message disposition for the OUTLOG= option. You can specify multiple LOGCONTROL= options. You can specify zero or more pairs. In these pairs, severity can take one of the following values: NONE specifies messages that have no severity classification. NOTE specifies messages whose severity classification is NOTE. WARNING specifies messages whose severity classification is WARNING. ERROR specifies messages whose severity classification is ERROR. You can specify the following values to indicate the associated message disposition: IGNORE ignores messages of the specified severity.
arguments.help: LOGCONTROL=NONE | NOTE | WARNING | ERROR | IGNORE | KEEP

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output table to contain the time series variables that are specified in the subsequent VAR statements.

arguments.name: OUTARRAY=
arguments.description: Names the output table to contain the time series vectors that are specified in the VAR and OUTARRAYS statements. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to the caslib and session identifier, and data-table specifies the name of the output data table.

arguments.name: OUTLOG=
arguments.description: Names the output table to contain textual messages that are collected from the execution of the BY-group processing.

arguments.name: OUTOBJ=
arguments.description: Specifies pairs, each of which binds a collector object specified by object-name with an output table specified by CAS-libref.data-table.

arguments.name: OUTSCALAR=
arguments.description: Names the output table to contain the scalar names that are specified in the OUTSCALARS statements. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to the caslib and session identifier, and data-table specifies the name of the output data table.

arguments.name: OUTSUM=
arguments.description: Names the output table to contain the descriptive statistics. CAS-libref.data-table is a two-level name, where CAS-libref refers to the caslib and session identifier, and data-table specifies the name of the output data table.

arguments.name: PUTTOLOG=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to capture messages from the PUT programming statement to the BY group’s row in the table that is specified in the OUTLOG= option.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies to captures messages.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies not to capture messages.

arguments.name: SEASONALITY=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of the seasonal cycle. For example, SEASONALITY=3 means that every group of three time periods forms a seasonal cycle. By default, the length of the seasonal cycle is 1 (no seasonality) or the length that is implied by the INTERVAL= option in the ID statement.

statements.name: ARRAY
statements.description: Associates a name with a list of variables and constants.

arguments.name: NOSYMBOLS
arguments.description: Specifies that an array of numeric or character values be created without the associated element variables. In this case, the only way you can access elements in the array is by array subscripting.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Specifies format, label, and length information for variables.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: Associates a format with variables in the variable argument.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: Associates a label with variables in the variable argument.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the length of the variable in the variable argument.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: You can include a BY statement with PROC TSMODEL to obtain separate processing for groups of observations that are defined by the BY variables. The rows in each distinct BY group are used to accumulate the time series vectors from the timestamped row data according to a desired frequency (which is specified in the INTERVAL= option) and the accumulation mode (which is specified in the ACCUMULATE= option).

statements.name: CALL
statements.description: Invokes a SAS CALL routine.

statements.name: CONTINUE
statements.description: Stops processing the current DO-loop iteration and resumes processing the next iteration.

statements.name: DATALINES4
statements.description: Indicates that data lines that contain semicolons follow.

statements.name: DATALINES
statements.description: Specifies that data lines follow.

statements.name: DELETE
statements.description: Stops processing the current observation.

statements.name: DELETEFUNC
statements.description: Causes a function to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option. Required Argument: function-name specifies the name of a function to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

statements.name: DELETESUBR
statements.description: Causes a subroutine to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option. Required Argument: subroutine-name specifies the name of a subroutine to be deleted from the function library that is specified in the OUTLIB option.

statements.name: DESCRIBE
statements.description: Retrieves source code from a stored compiled DATA step program or a DATA step view.

statements.name: DISPLAY
statements.description: Displays a window that is created with the WINDOW statement.

arguments.name: BELL
arguments.description: Produces an audible alarm, beep, or bell sound when the window is displayed if your personal computer is equipped with a speaker device that provides sound.

arguments.name: BLANK
arguments.description: Clears the window.

arguments.name: DELETE
arguments.description: Deletes the display of the window after processing passes from the DISPLAY statement on which the option appears.

arguments.name: NOINPUT
arguments.description: Specifies that you cannot input values into fields that are displayed in the window.

arguments.name: BY
arguments.description: Precedes an increment integer (other than 0) or an expression that generates an integer to be added to the value of the index variable in each iteration of the DO loop.

arguments.name: TO
arguments.description: Separates the start and stop integers or expressions that control the number of times the portion of the DATA step between the iterative DO and END statements is processed.

arguments.name: UNTIL
arguments.description: ...more SAS statements... END

statements.name: DROP
statements.description: Excludes variables from output SAS data sets.

statements.name: ELSE
statements.description: If the condition in an IF-THEN statement is false and an ELSE statement is present, then the ELSE action is carried out.

arguments.name: DO
arguments.description: DO statement in an IF-THEN/ELSE construct.

arguments.name: IF
arguments.description: Executes a SAS statement for observations that meet specific conditions.

arguments.name: THEN
arguments.description: If the conditions that are specified in the IF clause are met, the IF-THEN statement executes a SAS statement for observations that are read from a SAS data set, for records in an external file, or for computed values.

statements.name: END
statements.description: Ends a DO group or SELECT group processing.

statements.name: ENDRSUBMIT
statements.description: Marks the end of a block of statements that a client session submits to a server session for execution.

statements.name: ENDSUB
statements.description: Ends a FUNCTION or SUBROUTINE statement block.

statements.name: ENDSUBMIT
statements.description: The ENDSUBMIT statement is required to terminate the user-defined program statements in the PROC TSMODEL statement block whenever you specify the SUBMIT statement without the FILE= option.

statements.name: ERROR
statements.description: Sets _ERROR_ to 1. A message written to the SAS log is optional.

statements.name: EXECUTE
statements.description: Executes a stored compiled DATA step program.

statements.name: FILE
statements.description: Specifies the current output file for PUT statements.

arguments.name: BLKSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the block size of the output file.

arguments.name: COLUMN=
arguments.description: Specifies a variable that SAS automatically sets to the current column location of the pointer.

arguments.name: DELIMITER=
arguments.description: Specifies an alternate delimiter (other than a blank) to be used for LIST output.

arguments.name: DISK
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies that the device is a disk drive.

arguments.name: DLMSOPT=
arguments.description: Specifies a parsing option for the DLMSTR= T option that removes trailing blanks of the string delimiter.

arguments.name: 'T'
arguments.description: Removes trailing blanks of the string delimiter.

arguments.name: DLMSTR=
arguments.description: Specifies a character string as an alternate delimiter (other than a blank) to be used for LIST output

arguments.name: DROPOVER
arguments.description: Discards data items that exceed the output line length (as specified by the LINESIZE= or LRECL= options in the FILE statement).

arguments.name: DSD
arguments.description: Specifies that data values that contain embedded delimiters, such as tabs or commas, be enclosed in quotation marks.

arguments.name: DUMMY
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies that the output to the file is discarded. Tip: Specifying DUMMY can be useful for testing.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: Specifies the encoding to use when writing to the output file.

arguments.name: 'warabic'
arguments.description: Arabic

arguments.name: 'wbaltic'
arguments.description: Baltic

arguments.name: 'wlatin2'
arguments.description: Central Europe

arguments.name: 'wcyrillic'
arguments.description: Cyrillic

arguments.name: 'wgreek'
arguments.description: Greek

arguments.name: 'whebrew'
arguments.description: Hebrew

arguments.name: 'wturkish'
arguments.description: Turkish

arguments.name: 'wvietnamese'
arguments.description: Vietnamese

arguments.name: 'wlatin1'
arguments.description: Western

arguments.name: 'utf-8'
arguments.description: Unicode encoding

arguments.name: 'ms-950'
arguments.description: Traditional Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-936'
arguments.description: Simplified Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-932'
arguments.description: Japanese

arguments.name: 'ms-949'
arguments.description: Korean

arguments.name: FILENAME=
arguments.description: Defines a character variable, whose name you supply, that SAS sets to the value of the physical name of the file currently open for PUT statement output.

arguments.name: FILEVAR=
arguments.description: Defines a variable whose change in value causes the FILE statement to close the current output file and open a new one the next time the FILE statement executes.

arguments.name: FLOWOVER
arguments.description: Causes data that exceeds the current line length to be written on a new line.

arguments.name: FOOTNOTES
arguments.description: Specifies that the currently defined footnotes are printed.

arguments.name: GTERM
arguments.description: [device-type] Indicates that the output device type is a graphics device that will receive graphics data.

arguments.name: HEADER=
arguments.description: Defines a statement label that identifies a group of SAS statements that you want to execute each time SAS begins a new output page

arguments.name: LINE=
arguments.description: Defines a variable whose value is the current relative line number within the group of lines available to the output pointer.

arguments.name: LINESIZE=
arguments.description: Sets the maximum number of columns per line for reports and the maximum record length for data files.

arguments.name: LINESLEFT=
arguments.description: Defines a variable whose value is the number of lines left on the current page.

arguments.name: LOG
arguments.description: Is a reserved fileref that directs the output that is produced by any PUT statements to the SAS log.

arguments.name: LRECL=
arguments.description: Specifies the logical record length of the output file.

arguments.name: MOD
arguments.description: Writes the output lines after any existing lines in the file.

arguments.name: N=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lines that you want available to the output pointer in the current iteration of the DATA step.

arguments.name: <n>
arguments.description: Specifies the number of lines that are available to the output pointer. Replace n with an integer.

arguments.name: PAGESIZE
arguments.description: Specifies that the entire page is available to the output pointer.

arguments.name: NOFOOTNOTES
arguments.description: Specifies that the currently defined footnotes are not printed.

arguments.name: NOPAD
arguments.description: Specifies that records written to an external file are not padded with blanks to the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Specifies that carriage-control characters are placed in the output lines.

arguments.name: NOTITLES
arguments.description: Specifies that the current title lines are not printed on the pages of files.

arguments.name: ODS=
arguments.description: Specifies to use the Output Delivery System to format the output from a DATA step.

arguments.name: OLD
arguments.description: Replaces the previous contents of the file.

arguments.name: PAD
arguments.description: Specifies that records written to an external file are padded with blanks to the length that is specified in the LRECL= option.

arguments.name: PAGESIZE=
arguments.description: Sets the number of lines per page for your reports.

arguments.name: PIPE
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies an unnamed pipe. Note: Some operating environments do not support pipes.

arguments.name: PLOTTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies an unbuffered graphics output device.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Either a reserved fileref that directs the output that is produced by any PUT statements to the same file as the output that is produced by SAS procedures, or an option that specifies that carriage-control characters are placed in the output lines.

arguments.name: PRINTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a printer or printer spool file.

arguments.name: RECFM=
arguments.description: Specifies the record format of the output file.

arguments.name: STOPOVER
arguments.description: Stops processing the DATA step immediately if a PUT statement attempts to write a data item that exceeds the current line length.

arguments.name: TAPE
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a tape drive.

arguments.name: TEMP
arguments.description: [device-type] Creates a temporary file that exists only as long as the filename is assigned. Restriction: Do not specify a physical pathname. If you do, SAS returns an error.

arguments.name: TERMINAL
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies the user's terminal.

arguments.name: TITLES
arguments.description: Specifies that the current title lines are printed on the pages of files.

arguments.name: UPRINTER
arguments.description: [device-type] Specifies a Universal Printing printer definition name.

arguments.name: _FILE_=
arguments.description: StatementOptionNames a character variable that references the current output buffer of this FILE statement.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: Specifies a temporary default format for displaying the values of variables that are not listed in the FORMAT statement.

statements.name: FUNCTION
statements.description: Specifies a subroutine declaration for a routine that returns a value.

arguments.name: KIND=
arguments.description: Specifies a collection of items that have specific attributes.

arguments.name: VARARGS
arguments.description: Specifies that the function supports a variable number of arguments. If you specify VARARGS, then the last argument in the function must be an array.

statements.name: GOTO
statements.description: Jumps to a new statement.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement names a numeric variable that identifies the temporal order (time sequence) of observations in the input and output tables. The values of variables are assumed to be SAS date, SAS datetime, or observation values. In addition, the ID statement specifies the frequency to be associated with the time series. The ID statement options also specify a global treatment for how the time series variables are accumulated from the BY group’s rows and how the time ID values are aligned to form the time series. The specified information affects all variables that are specified in subsequent VAR statements. The ID statement and the INTERVAL= option are required to specify the desired accumulation frequency.
statements.help: ID <ACCUMULATE=<NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE>... > <ALIGN=<BEGINNING | MIDDLE | ENDING>> INTERVAL=DAY|HOUR|MINUTE...  ...

arguments.name: INTERVAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the frequency of the accumulated time series. For example, if the input table consists of quarterly observations, then specify INTERVAL=QTR. Interval names are constructed from a basic interval type with an optional multiplier and shift. The general form of an interval name is as follows:
arguments.help: INTERVAL=DAY | HOUR | MINUTE | SECOND | WEEK | MONTH | YEAR | QTR | TENDAY | SEMIMONTH | SEMIYEAR | WEEKDAY | YEARV | R445YR | R454YR | R544YR | R445QTR | R454QTR | R544QTR | R445MON | R454MON | R544MON | WEEKVinterval

arguments.name: DAY
arguments.description: Specifies daily intervals. Abbreviations are DAY, DAYS, and DAILY. The starting subperiod s is in days (DAY).

arguments.name: HOUR
arguments.description: Specifies hourly intervals. Aliases are HOUR, DTHOUR, HOURS, DTHOURS, HOURLY, DTHOURLY, HR, and DTHR. The starting subperiod s is in hours (HOUR).

arguments.name: MINUTE
arguments.description: Specifies minute intervals. Aliases are MINUTE, DTMINUTE, MINUTES, DTMINUTES, MIN, and DTMIN. The starting subperiod s is in minutes (MINUTE).

arguments.name: SECOND
arguments.description: Specifies second intervals. Aliases are SECOND, DTSECOND, SECONDS, DTSECONDS, SEC and DTSEC. The starting subperiod s is in seconds (SECOND).

arguments.name: WEEK
arguments.description: Specifies weekly intervals of seven days. Abbreviations are WEEK, WEEKS, and WEEKLY. The starting subperiod s is in days (DAY), with the days of the week numbered as 1=Sunday, 2=Monday, 3=Tuesday, 4=Wednesday, 5=Thursday, 6=Friday, and 7=Saturday. For example, WEEK.7 means weekly with Saturday as the first day of the week.

arguments.name: MONTH
arguments.description: Specifies monthly intervals. Abbreviations are MONTH, MONTHS, MONTHLY, and MON. The starting subperiod s is in months (MONTH). For example, MONTH2.2 intervals are February– March, April–May, June–July, August–September, October–November, and December–January of the following year.

arguments.name: YEAR
arguments.description: Specifies yearly intervals. Abbreviations are YEAR, YEARS, YEARLY, YR, ANNUAL, A NNUALLY, and ANNUALS. The starting subperiod s is in months (MONTH).

arguments.name: QTR
arguments.description: Specifies quarterly intervals (every three months). Abbreviations are QTR, QUARTER, QUARTERS, QUARTERLY, QTRLY, and QTRS. The starting subperiod s is in months (MONTH).

arguments.name: TENDAY
arguments.description: Specifies 10-day intervals. TENDAY breaks the month into three periods, the 1st through the 10th day of the month, the th through the th day of the month, and the remainder of the month. (TENDAY is a special interval typically used for reporting automobile sales data.) The starting subperiod s is in TENDAY periods.

arguments.name: SEMIMONTH
arguments.description: Specifies semimonthly intervals. SEMIMONTH breaks each month into two periods, starting on the st and th days. Abbreviations are SEMIMONTH, SEMIMONTHS, SEMIMONTHLY, and SEMIMON. The starting subperiod s is in SEMIMONTH periods.

arguments.name: SEMIYEAR
arguments.description: Specifies semiannual intervals (every six months). Abbreviations are SEMIYEAR, SEMIYEARS, SEMIYEARLY, SEMIYR, SEMIANNUAL, and SEMIANN. The starting subperiod s is in months (MONTH).

arguments.name: WEEKDAY
arguments.description: Specifies daily intervals with weekend days included in the preceding weekday. Note that for a five-day work week that starts on Monday, the appropriate interval is WEEKDAY5.2. Abbreviations are WEEKDAY and WEEKDAYS. The starting subperiod s is in weekdays (WEEKDAY).

arguments.name: YEARV
arguments.description: Specifies ISO 8601 yearly intervals. The ISO 8601 year starts on the Monday on or immediately preceding January th. Note that it is possible for the ISO 8601 year to start in December of the preceding year. Also, some ISO 8601 years contain a leap week.

arguments.name: R445YR
arguments.description: Is the same as YEARV except that the starting subperiod s is in retail 4-4-5 months (R445MON).

arguments.name: R454YR
arguments.description: Is the same as YEARV except that the starting subperiod s is in retail 4-5-4 months (R454MON).

arguments.name: R544YR
arguments.description: Is the same as YEARV except that the starting subperiod s is in retail 5-4-4 months (R544MON).

arguments.name: R445QTR
arguments.description: Specifies retail 4-4-5 quarterly intervals (every 13 ISO 8601 weeks). Some fourth quarters contain a leap week. The starting subperiod s is in retail 4-4-5 months (R445MON).

arguments.name: R454QTR
arguments.description: Specifies retail 4-5-4 quarterly intervals (every 13 ISO 8601 weeks). Some fourth quarters contain a leap week.

arguments.name: R544QTR
arguments.description: Specifies retail 5-4-4 quarterly intervals (every 13 ISO 8601 weeks). Some fourth quarters contain a leap week. The starting subperiod s is in retail 5-4-4 months (R544MON).

arguments.name: R445MON
arguments.description: Specifies retail 4-4-5 monthly intervals. The 3rd, 6th, 9th, and 12th months are five ISO 8601 weeks long with the exception that some th months contain leap weeks. All other months are four ISO 8601 weeks long. R445MON intervals begin with the 1st, 5th, 9th, 14th, 18th, 22nd, 27th, 31st, 35th, 40th, 44th, and 48th weeks of the ISO year. The starting subperiod s is in retail 4-4-5 months (R445MON).

arguments.name: R454MON
arguments.description: Specifies retail 4-5-4 monthly intervals. The 2nd, 5th, 8th, and 11th months are five ISO 8601 weeks long. All other months are four ISO 8601 weeks long with the exception that some 12th months contain leap weeks. R454MON intervals begin with the 1st, 5th, 10th, 14th, 18th, 23rd, 27th, 31st, 36th, 40th, 44th, and 49th weeks of the ISO year.

arguments.name: R544MON
arguments.description: Specifies retail 5-4-4 monthly intervals. The 1st, 4th, 7th, and 10th months are five ISO 8601 weeks long. All other months are four ISO 8601 weeks long with the exception that some th months contain leap weeks. R544MON intervals begin with the 1st, 6th, 10th, 14th, 19th, 23rd, 27th, 32nd, 36th, 40th, 45th, and 49th weeks of the ISO year. The starting subperiod s is in retail 5-4-4 months (R544MON).

arguments.name: WEEKV
arguments.description: Specifies ISO 8601 weekly intervals of seven days. Each week starts on Monday. The starting subperiod s is in days (DAY). Note that WEEKV differs from WEEK in that WEEKV.1 starts on Monday, WEEKV.2 starts on Tuesday, and so forth.

arguments.name: ACCUMULATE=
arguments.description: Specifies how the data set observations are accumulated within each time period. The frequency (width of each time interval) is specified by the INTERVAL= option.
arguments.help: ACCUMULATE=NONE | TOTAL | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | N | NMISS | NOBS | FIRST | LAST | STDDEV | CSS | USS

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: No accumulation occurs; the ID variable values must be equally spaced with respect to the frequency. This is the default option.

arguments.name: TOTAL
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the total sum of their values.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the average of their values.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the minimum of their values.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the median of their values.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the maximum of their values.

arguments.name: N
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of nonmissing observations.

arguments.name: NMISS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of missing observations.

arguments.name: NOBS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the number of observations.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the first of their values.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the last of their values.

arguments.name: STDDEV
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the standard deviation of their values.

arguments.name: CSS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the corrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: USS
arguments.description: Observations are accumulated based on the uncorrected sum of squares of their values.

arguments.name: ALIGN=
arguments.description: Controls the alignment of SAS date or datetime values that are used to identify the time period of output observations.

arguments.name: BEGINNING
arguments.description: Represents each time period using the beginning SAS date or datetime value of the time period.

arguments.name: MIDDLE
arguments.description: Represents each time period using the middle SAS date or datetime value of the time period. he middle is calculated as the average of the beginning and ending values.

arguments.name: ENDING
arguments.description: Represents each time period using the ending SAS date or datetime value of the time period.

arguments.name: END=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date or datetime value that represents the end of the data. If the last time ID variable value is less than value, then the series is extended with missing values. If the last time ID variable value is greater than value, then the series is truncated. For example, END="&sysdate"D uses the automatic macro variable SYSDATE to extend or truncate the series to the current date. You can specify the START= and END= options to ensure that the data that are associated within each BY group contain the same number of observations.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: Specifies the SAS format for the time ID values. If this option is not specified, the default format is inferred from the INTERVAL= option.

arguments.name: SETMISSING=
arguments.description: Specifies how to interpret missing values (either input or accumulated) in the accumulated time series.
arguments.help: SETMISSING=MISSING | AVERAGE | MINIMUM | MEDIAN | MAXIMUM | FIRST | LAST | PREVIOUS | NEXT | n

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Missing values are set to missing. This is the default option.

arguments.name: AVERAGE
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated average value.

arguments.name: MINIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated minimum value.

arguments.name: MEDIAN
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated median value.

arguments.name: MAXIMUM
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated maximum value.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated first nonmissing value.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the accumulated last nonmissing value.

arguments.name: PREVIOUS
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the previous accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the beginning of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: NEXT
arguments.description: Missing values are set to the next accumulated nonmissing value. Missing values at the end of the accumulated series remain missing.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: Interprets a missing value as having the value n.

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies a SAS date or datetime value that represents the beginning of the data.

arguments.name: TRIMID=
arguments.description: Specifies the method for trimming the data in the BY groups when time series vectors are input to the user-defined program. The output time ID variable span that is calculated by the method is dependent on the input time ID variable span, irrespective of missing values of the time series variables. Depending on the method and the input time ID variable data, leading or trailing missing values can be added to the time series variables.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Uses the same starting and ending values of the output time ID variable for all BY groups.

arguments.name: LEFT
arguments.description: Uses the identifying date for the first time period that is input for the BY group as the starting value of the output time ID variable for each BY group.

arguments.name: RIGHT
arguments.description: Uses the identifying date for the last time period that is input for the BY group as the ending value of the output time ID variable for each BY group.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Uses the span of the input time ID variable for the BY group as the span of the output time ID variable for each BY group.

arguments.name: DO
arguments.description: DO statement in an IF-THEN construct.

arguments.name: THEN
arguments.description: If the conditions that are specified in the IF clause are met, the IF-THEN statement executes a SAS statement for observations that are read from a SAS data set, for records in an external file, or for computed values.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: Specifies a temporary default informat for reading values of the variables that are listed in the INFORMAT statement. If no variable is specified, then the DEFAULT= informat specification applies a temporary default informat for reading values of all the variables of that type included in the DATA step. Numeric informats are applied to numeric variables, and character informats are applied to character variables. These default informats apply only to the current DATA step.

statements.name: INSCALARS
statements.description: The INSCALARS statement specifies which scalar variables to automatically include for your program to use. These variables can be numeric or character. Each variable that you name in an INSCALARS statement must be defined in the table specified in the INSCALAR= option in the PROC TSMODEL statement. You must specify at least one INSCALARS statement if you specify the INSCALAR= option in the PROC TSMODEL statement. You can specify multiple INSCALARS statements.

statements.name: KEEP
statements.description: Specifies the variables to include in output SAS data sets.

statements.name: KILLTASK
statements.description: For asynchronous tasks, forces one or more active tasks or server sessions to terminate immediately.

statements.name: LABEL
statements.description: Specifies a label of up to 256 characters.

statements.name: LEAVE
statements.description: Stops processing the current loop and resumes with the next statement in the sequence.

statements.name: LENGTH
statements.description: Specifies the number of bytes for storing variables.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: Changes the default number of bytes that SAS uses to store the values of any newly created numeric variables.

statements.name: LINK
statements.description: Directs program execution immediately to the statement label that is specified and, if followed by a RETURN statement, returns execution to the statement that follows the LINK statement.

statements.name: LIST
statements.description: Writes to the SAS log the input data record for the observation that is being processed.

statements.name: LISTFUNC
statements.description: Causes the source code for a function to be written to the SAS listing. Required Argument: function-name specifies the name of the function for which source code is written to the SAS listing.

statements.name: LISTSUBR
statements.description: Causes the source code for a subroutine to be written to the SAS listing. Required Argument: subroutine-name specifies the name of the subroutine for which source code is written to the SAS listing.

statements.name: LISTTASK
statements.description: Lists all active connections or tasks and identifies the execution status of each connection or task.

statements.name: LOCK
statements.description: Acquires and releases an exclusive lock on an existing SAS file.

arguments.name: CLEAR
arguments.description: Releases a lock on the specified SAS file that was acquired by using the LOCK statement in your SAS session.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: Writes to the SAS log whether you have an exclusive lock on the specified SAS file.

statements.name: LOSTCARD
statements.description: Resynchronizes the input data when SAS encounters a missing or invalid record in data that has multiple records per observation.

statements.name: MISSING
statements.description: Assigns characters in your input data to represent special missing values for numeric data.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

arguments.name: CATALOG=
arguments.description: By default, no value is assigned to CATALOG=, which means that temporary GRSEGs are not copied to a permanent catalog.

arguments.name: <permanent-catalog>
arguments.description: Copies any temporary GRSEG to the specified permanent catalog and keeps a reference to the permanent GRSEG in the document. This value persists until the ODS DOCUMENT statement is closed, or until you delete it by specifying CATALOG=_NULL_. The permanent catalog has the following form: <libref.><member-name>;

arguments.name: _NULL_
arguments.description: Deletes the catalog name that was previously specified for the CATALOG= option. Thereafter, temporary GRSEGs are not copied into the permanent catalog, and thus are unavailable in subsequent sessions.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: DIR=
arguments.description: Specifies the directory path and/or label for ODS output. LABEL=label assigns a label to a path. PATH= path <(access-option)> is specified as a sequence of entries that are delimited by backslashes. path can have the form: path<#sequence-number> where path is the name of the path. #sequence-number is a number which, when combined with a pathname, uniquely identifies the entry in the directory that contains it. access-option specifies the access mode for the ODS document. WRITE -- opens a document and provides write access as well as read access.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes one or more output objects from the DOCUMENT destination.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: Assigns a label to a path.

arguments.name: NAME=
arguments.description: Syntax: NAME= <libref.>member-name<(access-option)> where: libref specifies the SAS library where the document is stored. Default: If no library name is specified, the WORK library is used. member-name specifies the document name. access-option specifies the access mode for the ODS document. WRITE opens a document and provides write access as well as read access.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Is specified as a sequence of entries that are delimited by backslashes.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects one or more output objects for the DOCUMENT destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: UPDATE
arguments.description: [access-option] Opens an ODS document and appends new content to the document. UPDATE provides update access as well as read access.

arguments.name: WRITE
arguments.description: [access-option] Opens a document and provides write access as well as read access.

statements.name: ODS ESCAPECHAR=
statements.description: escape-character specifies the special character that identifies the inline formatting symbol. The escape-character should be one of the following rarely used characters: @, ^, or \.

statements.name: ODS GRAPHICS
statements.description: Enables or disables ODS graphics processing and sets graphics environment options. This statement affects ODS template-based graphics only. The ODS GRAPHICS statement does not affect device-based graphics.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Disables ODS Graphics processing.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Enables ODS Graphics processing. This is the default if no argument is used.

arguments.name: ANTIALIAS
arguments.description: Smooths jagged edges of all components in the graph.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Does not smooth jagged edges of components other than text in the graph.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Smooths jagged edges of all components in the graph.

arguments.name: ANTIALIASMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of markers or lines to be anti-aliased before anti-aliasing is disabled. Default: 1000

arguments.name: BORDER
arguments.description: Specifies whether to draw a border around the graph.

arguments.name: BORDER=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to draw a border around the graph.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Specifies not to draw a border around the graph.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Specifies to draw a border around the graph.

arguments.name: DISCRETEMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of discrete values to be shown in any graph. Default: 1000

arguments.name: GROUPMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of group values to be shown in any graph. Any graph that supports the GROUP= option is affected. Default: 1000

arguments.name: HEIGHT=
arguments.description: Specifies the height of any graph.

arguments.name: IMAGEFMT=
arguments.description: Specifies the image format to be used. If the image format is not valid for the active output destination, the format is automatically changed to the default image format for that destination.
arguments.help: IMAGEFMT=BMP | DIB | EMF | EPSI | GIF | JFIF | JPEG | PBM | PDF | PNG | PS | SASEMF | TIFF | WMF | STATIC

arguments.name: BMP
arguments.description: Microsoft Windows Device Independent Bitmap

arguments.name: DIB
arguments.description: Microsoft Windows Device Independent Bitmap

arguments.name: EMF
arguments.description: Microsoft NT Enhanced Metafile

arguments.name: EPSI
arguments.description: Microsoft NT Enhanced Metafile

arguments.name: GIF
arguments.description: Graphics Interchange Format

arguments.name: JFIF
arguments.description: JPEG File Interchange Format

arguments.name: JPEG
arguments.description: Joint Photographic Experts Group

arguments.name: PBM
arguments.description: Portable Bitmap Utilities

arguments.name: PDF
arguments.description: Portable Document Format

arguments.name: PNG
arguments.description: Portable Network Graphic

arguments.name: PS
arguments.description: PostScript Image File Format

arguments.name: SASEMF
arguments.description: Enhanced Metafile

arguments.name: TIFF
arguments.description: Tagged Image File Format

arguments.name: WMF
arguments.description: Microsoft Windows Metafile

arguments.name: STATIC
arguments.description: Uses the best quality static image format for the active output destination. This is the default.

arguments.name: IMAGEMAP
arguments.description: Specifies to generate data tips.

arguments.name: IMAGEMAP=
arguments.description: Specifies to generate data tips.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate data tips.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Specifies to generate data tips.

arguments.name: IMAGENAME=
arguments.description: Specifies the base image filename.

arguments.name: LABELMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of labeled areas before labeling is disabled.

arguments.name: MAXLEGENDAREA=
arguments.description: Specifies an integer that is interpreted as the maximum percentage of the overall graphics area that a legend can occupy. Default: 20

arguments.name: NOANTIALIAS
arguments.description: Does not smooth jagged edges of components other than text in the graph.

arguments.name: NOBORDER
arguments.description: Specifies not to draw a border around any graph.

arguments.name: NOIMAGEMAP
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate data tips.

arguments.name: NOSCALE
arguments.description: Does not scale the components of graph proportionally.

arguments.name: PANELCELLMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of cells in a graph panel where the number of cells is determined dynamically by classification variables. Default: 10000

arguments.name: RESET
arguments.description: Resets all of the options to their defaults.

arguments.name: RESET=
arguments.description: Resets the specified option to its default value.
arguments.help: RESET=ALL | ANTIALIAS | ANTIALIASMAX | BORDER | INDEX | HEIGHT | IMAGEMAP | LABELMAX | SCALE | TIPMAX | WIDTH

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Resets all of the reset-options to their defaults.

arguments.name: ANTIALIAS
arguments.description: Resets the ANTIALIAS option to its default.

arguments.name: ANTIALIASMAX
arguments.description: Resets the ANTIALIASMAX option to its default.

arguments.name: BORDER
arguments.description: Resets the BORDER= option to its default.

arguments.name: INDEX
arguments.description: Resets the index counter that is appended to static image files.

arguments.name: HEIGHT
arguments.description: Resets the HEIGHT= option to its default.

arguments.name: IMAGEMAP
arguments.description: Resets the IMAGEMAP= option to its default.

arguments.name: LABELMAX
arguments.description: Resets the LABELMAX= option to its default.

arguments.name: SCALE
arguments.description: Resets the SCALE= option to its default.

arguments.name: TIPMAX
arguments.description: Resets the TIPMAX= option to its default.

arguments.name: WIDTH
arguments.description: Resets the WIDTH= option to its default.

arguments.name: SCALE
arguments.description: Scales the components of graph proportionally.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of any graph. Requires a nonnegative number.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Does not scale the components of graph proportionally.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Scales the components of graph proportionally.

arguments.name: TIPMAX=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of distinct mouse-over areas allowed before data tips are disabled. Default: 500

arguments.name: WIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the width of any graph. Requires a nonnegative number.

statements.name: ODS LISTING
statements.help: ODS LISTING <EXCLUDE/SELECT ALL> <CLOSE> <EXCLUDE exclusion(s)| ALL | NONE> ...

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Excludes/Selects all output objects from the LISTING destination.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the LISTING destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: DATAPANEL=
arguments.description: Suggests how to split a table that is too wide to fit on a single page into sections of columns and rows. Each section of columns and rows is a data panel. Each data panel has column headings at the top.

arguments.name: <number>
arguments.description: Writes the specified number of observations in a panel, if possible. More than one panel can occur on every page if space permits. Range: 1 to the largest integer that the operating system supports.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Bases the size of the panel on the way that the table is stored in memory. This value provides the fastest performance. However, if the table contains many columns, the number of rows in each panel might be small.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: Tries to make panels that match the page size. If the table contains more columns than can fit on a page, the first page is filled with as many observations as possible for as many columns as can fit on a single line. The second page contains the same observations for the next group of columns, and so on, until all rows and columns have been printed.

arguments.name: DEVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default device for each open output destination.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes one or more output objects from the LISTING destination.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the file to write to. file-specification is one of the following: 'external-file' is the name of an external file to which to write.

arguments.name: GPATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the location for all graphics output that is generated while the destination is open. file-specification specifies the file or SAS catalog to which to write. file-specification is one of the following: external-file is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. libref.catalog specifies a SAS catalog to which to write. URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE specifies a URL for file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file. Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: IMAGE_DPI=
arguments.description: Specifies the image resolution of ODS graphics output. Output from device-based graphics is not affected. Default: 100

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Excludes/Selects no output objects from the LISTING destination.

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects output objects for the LISTING destination.

arguments.name: SGE=
arguments.description: Determines whether you can edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: Turns on the ability to edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: Turns off the ability to edit ODS graphics output with the ODS Graphics Editor.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: URL=
arguments.description: Specifies a URL for file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file. Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: BODY=
arguments.description: Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains the primary output that is created by the ODS statement. VNO_BOTTOM_MATTER|NO_TOP_MATTER|TITLE=|URL=|DYNAMIC

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

arguments.name: ANCHOR=
arguments.description: Specifies a unique base name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object in the current body file.

arguments.name: ARCHIVE=
arguments.description: The ARCHIVE= option is only valid for the GOPTIONS Java device. The ARCHIVE= option allows you to specify a string to identify which applet to use in order to view the ODS HTML output.

arguments.name: ATTRIBUTES=
arguments.description: Writes the specified attributes between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: Specifies the text to use as the first part of all links and references that ODS creates in the output files.

arguments.name: CHARSET=
arguments.description: Specifies the character set to be generated in the META declaration for the HTML output.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: CODE=
arguments.description: Opens a MARKUP family destination and specifies the file that contains relevant style information, such as XSL (Extensible Stylesheet Language).

arguments.name: CODEBASE=
arguments.description: Creates a file path that is used by the GOPTIONS devices.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: Opens a markup family destination and specifies the file that contains a table of contents for the output. These files remain open until you do one of the following: o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement. o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file. file-specification -- specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following: external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to.

arguments.name: DEVICE=
arguments.description: Specifies the name of a device driver. ODS automatically selects an optimal default device for each open output destination.

arguments.name: ENCODING=
arguments.description: Overrides the encoding for input or output processing (transcodes) of external files.

arguments.name: 'warabic'
arguments.description: Arabic

arguments.name: 'wbaltic'
arguments.description: Baltic

arguments.name: 'wlatin2'
arguments.description: Central Europe

arguments.name: 'wcyrillic'
arguments.description: Cyrillic

arguments.name: 'wgreek'
arguments.description: Greek

arguments.name: 'whebrew'
arguments.description: Hebrew

arguments.name: 'wturkish'
arguments.description: Turkish

arguments.name: 'wvietnamese'
arguments.description: Vietnamese

arguments.name: 'wlatin1'
arguments.description: Western

arguments.name: 'utf-8'
arguments.description: Unicode encoding

arguments.name: 'ms-950'
arguments.description: Traditional Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-936'
arguments.description: Simplified Chinese

arguments.name: 'ms-932'
arguments.description: Japanese

arguments.name: 'ms-949'
arguments.description: Korean

arguments.name: EVENT=
arguments.description: Specifies an event and the value for event variables that are associated with the event.
arguments.help: EVENT=FILE= | FINISH | LABEL= | NAME | START | STYLE= | TARGET= | TEXT= | URL=

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes one or more output objects from the destination.

arguments.name: FRAME=
arguments.description: Opens a MARKUP family destination and, for HTML output, specifies the file that integrates the table of contents, the page contents, and the body file.

arguments.name: GFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Prints footnotes that are created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the SGSCATTER procedure. The footnotes appear inside the graph borders. If you open the frame file, then you see a table of contents, a table of pages, or both, as well as the body file. For XLM output, FRAME= specifies the file that contains the DTD. These files remain open until you do one of the following: o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement. o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file. file-specification specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following: external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to.

arguments.name: GPATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the location for all graphics output that is generated while the destination is open. 'aggregate-file-storage-location' specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set. Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to. URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator -- is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file. Requirement: You must enclose Uniform-Resource-Locator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: GTITLE
arguments.description: Prints the title that is created by SAS/GRAPH, the SGPLOT procedure, the SGPANEL procedure, or the SGSCATTER procedure. The title appears inside the graph borders.

arguments.name: HEADTEXT=
arguments.description: where: markup-document-head specifies the markup tags to place between the <HEAD> and </HEAD> tags.

arguments.name: ID=
arguments.description: Enables you to run multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each instance can have different options.

arguments.name: IMAGE_DPI=
arguments.description: Specifies the image resolution for graphical output. Default: 100. Restriction: The IMAGE_DPI= option affects template-based graphics only.

arguments.name: METATEXT=
arguments.description: where: 'metatext-for-document-head' specifies the HTML code that provides the browser with information about the document that it is loading. For example, this attribute could specify the content type and the character set to use.

arguments.name: NEWFILE=
arguments.description: Creates a new body file at the specified starting-point.

arguments.name: BYGROUP
arguments.description: Starts a new file for the results of each BY group.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Writes all output to the body file that is currently open.

arguments.name: OUTPUT
arguments.description: Starts a new body file for each output object.

arguments.name: PAGE
arguments.description: Starts a new body file for each page of output.

arguments.name: PROC
arguments.description: Starts a new body file each time that you start a new procedure.

arguments.name: NOGFOOTNOTE
arguments.description: Prints footnotes that are created by ODS, which appears outside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NOGTITLE
arguments.description: Prints the title that is created by ODS, which appears outside the graph borders.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: See the SELECT or EXCLUDE option.

arguments.name: OPTIONS
arguments.description: Specifies tagset-specific suboptions and a named value. (DOC='QUICK' | 'HELP' | 'SETTINGS') provides information about the specified tagset. QUICK describes the options available for this tagset. HELP provides generic help and information with a quick reference. SETTINGS provides the current option settings. suboption(s) specifies one or more suboptions that are valid for the specified tagset. Supoptions have the following format:

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package.

arguments.name: PAGE=
arguments.description: Opens a markup family destination and specifies the file that contains a description of each page of the body file, and contains links to the body file. ODS produces a new page of output whenever a procedure requests a new page. These files remain open until you do one of the following: o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement. o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file. file-specification specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following: external-file -- is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. Interaction: If you specify an entry name, you must also specify a library and catalog.

arguments.name: PARAMETERS=
arguments.description: Writes the specified parameters between the tags that generate dynamic graphics output. parameter-pair specifies the name and value of each parameter. parameter-pair has the following form: 'parameter-name'= 'parameter-value' where: parameter-name -- is the name of the parameter.

arguments.name: PATH=
arguments.description: Specifies the location of an aggregate storage location or a SAS catalog for all markup files. If the GPATH= option is not specified, all graphics output files are written to the "aggregate-file-storage-specification" or libref. 'aggregate-file-storage-location' -- specifies an aggregate storage location such as directory, folder, or partitioned data set. Requirement: You must enclose aggregate-file-storage-location in quotation marks. fileref -- is a file reference that has been assigned to an aggregate storage location. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. Interaction: If you use a fileref in the PATH= option, then ODS does not use information from PATH= when it constructs links. libref.catalog -- specifies a SAS catalog to write to. URL= 'Uniform-Resource-Locator' | NONE -- specifies a URL for the file-specification. Uniform-Resource-Locator is the URL you specify. ODS uses this URL instead of the filename in all the links and references that it creates to the file.

arguments.name: RECORD_SEPARATOR=
arguments.description: Specifies an alternative character or string that separates lines in the output files. Different operating environments use different separator characters. If you do not specify a record separator, then the files are formatted for the environment where you run the SAS job. However, if you are generating files for viewing in a different operating environment that uses a different separator character, then you can specify a record separator that is appropriate for the target environment. alternative-separator -- represents one or more characters in hexadecimal or ASCII format. For example, the following option specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system: RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D0A'x Operating Environment Information: In a mainframe environment, the option that specifies a record separator for a carriage return character and a linefeed character for use with an ASCII file system is: RECORD_SEPARATOR= '0D25'x Requirement: You must enclose alternative-separator in quotation marks.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects one or more output objects for the specified destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the style definition to use in writing the output files.

arguments.name: STYLESHEET=
arguments.description: Opens a markup family destination and places the style information for markup output into an external file, or reads style sheet information from an existing file. These files remain open until you do one of the following: o close the destination with either an ODS markup-family-destination CLOSE statement or ODS _ALL_ CLOSE statement. o open the same destination with a second markup family statement. This closes the first file and opens the second file. file-specification -- specifies the file, fileref, or SAS catalog to write to. file-specification is one of the following: external-file is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. entry.markup -- specifies an entry in a SAS catalog to write to. Interaction: If you specify an entry name, you must also specify a library and catalog. See the discussion of the PATH= option.

arguments.name: TAGSET=
arguments.description: Specifies a keyword value for a tagset. A tagset is a template that defines how to create an output type from a SAS format.
arguments.help: TAGSET=CHTML | CORE | CSV | CSVALL | CSVBYLINE | DEFAULT | DOCBOOK | ExcelXP | HTML4 | HTMLCSS | HTMLPANEL | IMODE | MSOFFICE2K | MVSHTML | PHTML | PYX | RTF | SASREPORT | WML | WMLOLIST | XHTML | EVENT_MAP | NAMEDHTML | SHORT_MAP | STYLE_DISPLAY | STYLE_POPUP | TEXT_MAP | TPL_STYLE_LIST | TPL_STYLE_MAP

arguments.name: CHTML
arguments.description: Produces compact, minimal HTML output that does not use style information.

arguments.name: CORE
arguments.description: Contains a table of Unicode values and mnemonics.

arguments.name: CSV
arguments.description: Produces tabular output that contains columns of data values that are separated by commas.

arguments.name: CSVALL
arguments.description: Produces tabular output with titles that contain columns of data values that are separated by commas.

arguments.name: CSVBYLINE
arguments.description: Produces output with comma-separated values and columns of data that are separated by commas.

arguments.name: DEFAULT
arguments.description: Produces XML output.

arguments.name: DOCBOOK
arguments.description: Produces XML output that conforms to the DocBook DTD by OASIS.

arguments.name: ExcelXP
arguments.description: Produces Microsoft's spreadsheetML XML. This tagset is used to import data into XML.

arguments.name: HTML4
arguments.description: Produces HTML 4.0 embedded style sheets.

arguments.name: HTMLCSS
arguments.description: produces HTML output with cascading style sheets that is similar to ODS HTML output.

arguments.name: HTMLPANEL
arguments.description: Creates panels for By-grouped graphs.

arguments.name: IMODE
arguments.description: produces HTML output as a column of output that is separated by lines.

arguments.name: MSOFFICE2K
arguments.description: Produces HTML code for output generated by ODS for Microsoft Office products.

arguments.name: MVSHTML
arguments.description: Produces URLs within HTML files that are used in the z/OS operating environment.

arguments.name: PHTML
arguments.description: Produces simple HTML output that uses twelve style elements and no class attributes.

arguments.name: PYX
arguments.description: Produces PYX, which is a simple, line-oriented notation used by Pyxie to describe the information communicated by an XML parser to an XML application.

arguments.name: RTF
arguments.description: Produces measured RTF.

arguments.name: SASREPORT
arguments.description: Causes imbedded data to be produced in CSV format.

arguments.name: WML
arguments.description: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with a list of URLs as a table of contents.

arguments.name: WMLOLIST
arguments.description: Uses the Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to produce a Wireless Markup Language (WML) DTD with an option list for the table of contents.

arguments.name: XHTML
arguments.description: Produces output in HTML format.

arguments.name: EVENT_MAP
arguments.description: Creates XML output that shows which events are being triggered and which variables are used by an event to send output from a SAS process to an output file.

arguments.name: NAMEDHTML
arguments.description: Creates HTML output similar to STYLE_POPUP, but with all the objects labeled as they are when using ODS TRACE.

arguments.name: SHORT_MAP
arguments.description: Creates a subset of the XML output that is created by the EVENT_MAP tagset.

arguments.name: STYLE_DISPLAY
arguments.description: Creates a sample page of HTML output that is similar to STYLE_POPUP output.

arguments.name: STYLE_POPUP
arguments.description: Creates HTML like HTMLCSS, but if you're using Internet Explorer, STYLE_POPUP displays a window that shows the resolved ODS style definition for any item that you select.

arguments.name: TEXT_MAP
arguments.description: Creates text output that shows which events are being triggered as ODS handles the output objects.

arguments.name: TPL_STYLE_LIST
arguments.description: Creates HTML output in a bulleted list similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the possible attributes.

arguments.name: TPL_STYLE_MAP
arguments.description: Creates XML output similar to EVENT_MAP but lists only a subset of the possible attributes.

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: Inserts text into your document by triggering the paragraph event and specifying a text string to be assigned to the VALUE event variable.

arguments.name: TRANTAB=
arguments.description: Specifies the translation table to use when transcoding a file for output.

statements.name: ODS NOPROCTITLE
statements.description: Suppresses the writing of the title of the procedure that produces the results.

statements.name: ODS NOUSEGOPT
statements.description: Specifies that ODS not use traditional SAS/GRAPH option settings for non-graphical output.

arguments.name: CLEAR
arguments.description: Sets the list for the OUTPUT destination to EXCLUDE ALL.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the OUTPUT destination. When an ODS destination is closed, ODS does not send output to that destination. Closing a destination frees some system resources.

arguments.name: MATCH_ALL=
arguments.description: Creates a new data set for each output object.

arguments.name: NOWARN
arguments.description: Suppresses the warning that an output object was requested but not created.

arguments.name: PERSIST=
arguments.description: Determines when ODS closes any data sets that it is creating, and determines when ODS removes output objects from the selection list for the OUTPUT destination.

arguments.name: PROC
arguments.description: Maintains the list of definitions even after the procedure ends, until you explicitly modify it.

arguments.name: RUN
arguments.description: Maintains the list of definitions and keeps open the data sets that it is creating even if the procedure or DATA step ends, or until you explicitly modify the list.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes to the SAS log the current selection or exclusion list for the OUTPUT destination. If the list is the default list (EXCLUDE ALL), then SHOW also writes the current overall selection or exclusion list.

statements.name: ODS PRINTER
statements.description: Syntax: (1) ODS PRINTER <(<ID=>identifier)> <action>; (2) ODS PRINTER <(<ID=>identifier)> <option(s)>;

arguments.name: NEWFILE=
arguments.description: Creates a new file at the specified starting-point. V

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

arguments.name: ANCHOR=
arguments.description: Specifies the root name for the anchor tag that identifies each output object in the current file.

arguments.name: AUTHOR=
arguments.description: Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the author.

arguments.name: BASE=
arguments.description: base-text is the text that ODS uses as the first part of all references that ODS creates in the file. Consider this specification:

arguments.name: BOOKMARKGEN
arguments.description: Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

arguments.name: BOOKMARKGEN=
arguments.description: Controls the generation of bookmarks in a PDF file.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Specifies to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

arguments.name: BOOKMARKLIST=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to generate and display the list of bookmarks for a PDF file.

arguments.name: HIDE
arguments.description: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are not automatically displayed when you open the PDF file.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate a list of bookmarks for your PDF file.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Generates a list of bookmarks for your PDF file. The bookmarks are automatically displayed when you open the PDF file.

arguments.name: CLOSE
arguments.description: Closes the destination and any files that are associated with it.

arguments.name: COLOR=
arguments.description: Applies the specified color scheme to your output.

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: Creates full color output for both text and graphics.

arguments.name: GRAY
arguments.description: Creates gray scale output for both text and graphics.

arguments.name: MONO
arguments.description: Creates monochromatic output for both text and graphics.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Does not use all the color information that the style definition provides.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Uses all the color information that a style definition provides, including background color.

arguments.name: COLUMNS=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of columns to place across each page of output. n is the number columns per page.

arguments.name: COMPRESS=
arguments.description: Controls the compression of a PDF file. Compression reduces the size of the file. n specifies the level of compression. The larger the number, the greater the compression. For example, n=0 is completely uncompressed, and n=9 is the maximum compression level.

arguments.name: CONTENTS
arguments.description: Generates a printable table of contents page.

arguments.name: CONTENTS=
arguments.description: Controls the generation of a printable table of contents.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Does not generate a printable table of contents.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Generates a printable table of contents.

arguments.name: CSSSTYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies a cascading style sheet to apply to your output. file-specification specifies a file, fileref, or URL that contains CSS code. file-specification is one of the following: "external-file" is the name of the external file. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks. fileref is a file reference that has been assigned to an external file. Use the FILENAME statement to assign a fileref. "URL" is a URL to an external file. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks.

arguments.name: DPI=
arguments.description: Specifies the image resolution for output files. Default: 150 Restriction: The DPI= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

arguments.name: EXCLUDE
arguments.description: Excludes output objects from the destination.

arguments.name: FILE=
arguments.description: Specifies the file that contains the output. external-file is the name of an external file to write to. Requirement: You must enclose external-file in quotation marks.

arguments.name: HOST
arguments.description: Specifies that ODS use the printer drivers that the host system provides. Interaction: In an ODS printer family statement that refers to an open ODS PRINTER destination, the HOST option forces ODS to close the destination and all files that are associated with it, and to open a new instance of the destination.

arguments.name: ID=
arguments.description: Enables you to open multiple instances of the same destination at the same time. Each instance can have different options.

arguments.name: KEYWORDS=
arguments.description: Inserts into the output file's metadata, a string of keywords. Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. Restriction: The KEYWORDS= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

arguments.name: NOBOOKMARKGEN
arguments.description: Specifies not to generate bookmarks in the PDF file.

arguments.name: NOCONTENTS
arguments.description: Does not generate a printable table of contents.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: See the EXCLUDE or SELECT option.

arguments.name: NOPDFNOTE
arguments.description: Modifies the behavior of PDFMARK so that notes are not added to the file for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

arguments.name: NOTOC
arguments.description: Specifies that ODS omit the table of contents (Bookmark list) that is produced by default when producing PDF or PDFMARK output.

arguments.name: PACKAGE
arguments.description: Specifies that the output from the destination be added to a package. package-name specifies the name of a package that was created with the ODS PACKAGE statement. If no name is specified, then the output is added to the unnamed package that was opened last.

arguments.name: PCL
arguments.description: Creates PCL output. Restriction: Do not use this option in conjunction with the PDF or PS option.

arguments.name: PDF
arguments.description: Creates PDF output. Restriction: Do not use this option in conjunction with the PCL or PS option.

arguments.name: PDFMARK
arguments.description: Enables ODS to insert special tags into a PostScript file. When you use software such as Adobe Acrobat (not Adobe Viewer), Acrobat Distiller interprets the tags to create a PDF file that contains the following items: o bookmarks for each section of the output and for each table. o references for items that are associated with the URL= style attribute. o notes for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute. Notes are optional, and are based on the PDFNOTE option.

arguments.name: PDFNOTE
arguments.description: Adds notes to a PDF file for items that are associated with the FLYOVER= style attribute.

arguments.name: PDFTOC=
arguments.description: Controls the level of the expansion of the table of contents in PDF documents.

arguments.name: PRINTER=
arguments.description: Creates output that is formatted for the specified printer. Default: If you do not specify a printer, then ODS formats the printer output for the printer that is specified by one of two SAS system options: o SYSPRINT= if you are using the Windows operating environment and do not specify any of the following options: PCL, PDFMARK, POSTSCRIPT, PS, or SAS.

arguments.name: PS
arguments.description: Creates PostScript output.

arguments.name: SELECT
arguments.description: Selects output objects for the specified destination.

arguments.name: SHOW
arguments.description: Writes the current selection or exclusion list for the destination to the SAS log.

arguments.name: STARTPAGE=
arguments.description: Controls page breaks.

arguments.name: NEVER
arguments.description: Specifies not to insert page breaks, even before graphics procedures.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: Specifies that no new pages be inserted at the beginning of each procedure, or within certain procedures, even if new pages are requested by the procedure code. A new page will begin only when a page is filled or when you specify STARTPAGE=NOW.

arguments.name: NOW
arguments.description: Forces the immediate insertion of a new page.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: Inserts a new page at the beginning of each procedure, and within certain procedures, as requested by the procedure code.

arguments.name: STYLE=
arguments.description: Specifies the style definition to use in writing the printer output.

arguments.name: SUBJECT=
arguments.description: Inserts into the metadata of a file the text string that you specify as the subject. subject-text is the text in the metadata of a file that indicates the subject. Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. Restriction: The SUBJECT= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

arguments.name: TEXT=
arguments.description: Inserts a text string into your output. Requirement: You must enclose text-string in quotation marks.

arguments.name: TITLE=
arguments.description: Inserts into the metadata of a file, the text string that you specify as the title. Restriction: Use this option only with the ODS PDF statement, the ODS PS statement with the PDFMARK option specified, and the ODS PRINTER statement with the PDFMARK option specified. Restriction: The TITLE= option takes effect only if specified at the opening of a file.

arguments.name: UNIFORM
